I humbly serve you.
Respected, well-learned, dear godfather. How well I had myself weighed, I would not be burdened with any business in these dangerous times, the state that I the proclamation, so with the five cities, would experience and report to my lord, looking at that the past time of trust, was not only disrespected but also rebellious are trained; But now the zeal of the fatherland forces me to take on this business, which I think is nothing but a rebellious trick (so that the robbers remain undetected and the pious are oppressed), and to take it on. Specifically the business: I have gone to Blyggenstorff today, to the robbers and thieves, where I unexpectedly encountered a trusting man from Barr, who told me that they had been in disorder and had kept a watch last night; The cause of this watch was told to him by one of the councilors, so that an important warning letter had come to them from the lords of Zurich, that they should take good care, because they might be master of their names. And the same councilor said to him: "Summer goat's load, we have now received enough warning, because if an authority gives us warning, we have enough right to be on guard; If they do not keep peace, then it is in danger, we will attack them, because we will be attacked by them. "
The same man also told me that they had argued various things from this warning.

seg.output:
Dear wise, learned and beloved godfather. How deeply I have been affected by these times, I would not burden anyone with this affair, but I wanted to find out and report it to my lord, seeing that past times had not only been neglected but also trained in rebellion; but now the zeal of the fatherland forces me to accept this affair, which does not seem to me anything else but a rebellious trick (so that the robbers remain unpunished and the pious oppressed). Namely, the matter: I went to Blyggenstorff today, to ratify the rabbits and trodden, and there unexpectedly met a trusted companion from Barr who told me that they had been in unrest and had set a watch the night before; the reason for this watch had been told to him by one of the councilors, so that they had received a written warning from the lords of Zurich to be careful, as they could not be sure of their masters. And this same councilor had said to him: "We must bear the burden, for now we have received enough warning, since a sovereign warning forces us to be on guard; if they do not have rest, it is certain that we will attack them, for we will be attacked by them." The same companion also told me that they were arguing about different things from this warning. Some said: "Those in town are afraid that the community will fall against the town, and so that they may have rest, they want to punish us against the country".
I did not want to keep such news from you as a faithful watchman, so that you can act according to your opinion and according to the laws of the course. I would not write anything else to anyone; there are many people either so corrupt or so attached to the corruptions of the measure that no one knows whom to trust. Let me, if something should happen, act according to my trust. May God be blessed.
Date Monday soon after the Exaltation of the Cross 1532.
Petrus Simler.
To the esteemed, learned and respected Master Heinrich Bulli, preacher of Zurich, my beloved lord and godfather.

seg.output: My humble service to you. I, though not expert, but devoted, my dear lord, had intended to not take any part in the current tumultuous times. I had intended to observe and report to my lord the events that took place in the five districts, so that the former loyal ones would not be disregarded, and the rebellious would be disciplined. However, the zeal of the fatherland compels me to take part in this endeavor, which in my opinion is nothing but a rebellious ploy (whereby the wicked are emboldened and the righteous oppressed). Namely, the affair: I went to Bleichenstorff today, to the robbers and looters, and unexpectedly met a trusted companion of Barr. He told me that they had had a commotion and a watch the night before; the cause of this watch was told by one of the councilmen, that a letter of warning had come from the Lords of Zurich, that they should take care, lest they should be overpowered by them. And the same councilman said to him: “Summer bocks lyden, now we have received enough warning, since an authority has issued us a warning, so we have enough right to be on our guard; if they do not keep peace, then we shall attack them, so that we shall not be the ones to be overrun by them.” The same companion also told me that they argued much from this warning.

Dear wise and learned master, dear uncle. How happy I was to be exempt from this dangerous time, that no one would be burdened by it, that I might hear the news, that it is said to be among the five towns, that the past warnings have not been ignored, but the rebellious are being trained; but now the zeal of the fatherland compels me to consider this affair, which to me appears nothing else than an act of rebellion, and which will bring about robbery and oppression of the innocent. Therefore I went yesterday to Blyggenstorff to the robbers and robbers' houses, and there I met an acquaintance of Barrs who told me that last night there had been an uproar and a watch had been raised, and that the reason for this watch had been told him by one of the councillors, that a letter of warning had come from the lords of Zurich, that they should take good care, for their masters were coming. And he said further that the same councillor had said to him: "Now that we have sufficient warning, if they do not give us rest, then it is likely that we will attack them, lest they surprise us." He also told me that they were making various deductions from this warning. Some said: "Those in the city are afraid that the community will take sides with the city, and that in order to have rest they want to submit us to the government again."
I did not want to withhold such a thing from you as a faithful guardian, that you may consider and act according to the circumstances. I do not want to write anything to anyone else; there are so many people either corrupted or subject to corruption, that no one knows who to trust. Therefore, if anything should happen, let me be informed according to my faith. May God be with us.
Dated Monday after the Feast of the Exaltation of the Cross 1532.
Peter Simler
To the wise, learned master Heinrich Bulli, preacher at Zurich, my dear master and uncle.
